chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: Any reform of the Electoral College should aim to make the winner align more reliably with the voters’ choice while keeping a meaningful role for states and avoiding sudden, destabilizing changes. A workable compromise is to reduce winner-take-all by using a proportional allocation of electors with a small statewide bonus, paired with nonpartisan national baselines for registration, recount triggers, audits, and certification timelines. This approach would broaden campaign incentives beyond a few battleground states and improve trust by making the rules clearer, more uniform, and harder to game.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: The Electoral College can be retained for stability and a meaningful state role, but modernized so outcomes track voters more closely and fewer communities feel ignored. A practical compromise is to allocate each state’s electors proportionally or by district with a modest statewide component, paired with clear, uniform national standards for ballot access, recounts, audits, and certification so every lawful vote is treated consistently. These reforms reduce winner-take-all distortions and swing-state incentives while strengthening transparency, security, and trust across urban and rural areas alike.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: A workable reform should make the presidential election track the voters’ will more closely while still respecting states and smaller communities. A practical compromise is to keep the Electoral College but end winner-take-all by allocating electors proportionally (or by district with clear anti-gerrymandering rules), and require electors to follow the certified vote. Pair this with uniform national baselines for ballot access, recounts, audits, and election security so every lawful vote is counted consistently and results are easier to trust across regions and parties.
